bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Walter M. Simpson, June 18, 1941

div1.p: Hench sends Simpson a photograph from the Cornwell painting unveiling and comments on Kissinger's condition after his stroke. He is not sure that the medical journal publishers are as interested in his yellow fever speech as Simpson believes them to be.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Walter M. Simpson, June 18, 1941
div1.p:
By separate post, I am sending you the photo-
graph which you wish. You will of course recognize Cornwell
on the left next to me, and Kissinger on the right. I
appreciate very much your interest in my talk. I wonder,
however, whether Hoeber and Fishbein were as interested as
they let on to you. I have heard from neither of them.
I understand that you gave Hoeber a copy but had none for
Fishbein. I will get in touch with him. Meanwhile, I
certainly appreciate your kind words about it.

I have just heard again from Mrs. Kissinger.
He continues to be completely paralyzed on the right side,
apparently partially blind, conscious only at times, com-
pletely helpless but still holding his own. I can only
hope that he will soon have a merciful release.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
